entry.title: Re: Unable to create new purchase order Header text
entry.content:
Hi,

You cannot add new standard text types directly in the configuration screen using the SSCUI. 

The system is designed to allow only SAP-delivered text types. 

You may monitor the idea submitted in the customer influence portal for more updates https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/310999

Best regards,

Krithika

entry.title: Re: Creating Purchase Order Header text ID's in SAP S4 HA...

Hi,

You cannot add new standard text types directly in the configuration screen using the SSCUI. 

The system is designed to allow only SAP-delivered text types. There are no BAdI's or CDS views which caters this requirement.

You may monitor the idea submitted in the customer influence portal for more updates https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/310999

Best regards,

Krithika

entry.title: The Data Service Request is required to be conditional. Try using the "If-Match" headernull
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am trying to update a Custom Field of a Billing Document (aka customer invoice) on Public Cloud from SAP Integration Suite.

SAP provides 2 different APIs for Billing Documents:
ODATA V2: https://api.sap.com/api/API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV/overview
ODATA V4: https://api.sap.com/api/sap-s4-CE_BILLINGDOCUMENT_0001-v1/overview

Unlike for Sales Orders, where the V2 can be used for PATCH calls, for Billing Documents, only the ODATA V4 has the option to PATCH the object.
However, when I try using the ODATA V4 adaptor in Integration Suite, it gives the following error:
"The Data Service Request is required to be conditional. Try using the "If-Match" headernull [HTTP/1.1 428 Precondition Required]."

My steps are: 

Request Reply: ODATA V4 - a simple GET call to retrieve the E-tag in the header for the given Billing Docuement
Content Modifier: Create Body and Add "If-Match" on the Header from the E-tag
Request Reply: ODATA V4 - PATCH to update a custom field

But the PATCH call fails:

I have also tried to set the "If-Match" to *, but I get the same error.

The same steps for the Sales Order ODATA V2 is working, but I the Billing Document ODATA V4 gives me the above error.

Am I missing something, or am I doing something wrong?
Or is the ODATA V4 adaptor broken?

Any tips would be appreciated.

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Re: Call Successfactors API from a SAP CAP application us...
entry.content: The "SF user id" is the id by which users are identified inside successfactors. Like 'sfadmin' for an admin user. It could be email addresses or firstlastname usernames, ... Whatever it is, that value has to be available somewhere in the IAS profile in a chosen field, and this field (e.g. "login name" or "custom attribute 1") has to be added into the IAS Assertion Attributes to be included in the JWT. Then in the Destination set userIdSource to the path in the token where to find it. See also: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/configure-user-attributes-sent-to-application

entry.title: Re: Investment indicator
entry.content:
Hello @jantoniomoyano3 

For SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, the Investment Indicator is a country-specific field primarily relevant in localisations such as France, where it triggers specific tax or reporting procedures for capital investment transactions.

In Spain, this indicator is inactive and does not affect standard financial processing or legal reporting. Therefore, selecting it in the Create Incoming Invoices (FB60) app results in no change in posting behaviour or subsequent processes.

You can confirm this by reviewing the Spanish localisation scope in the SAP Help Portal and Feature Scope Description. There is no mapping or specific logic associated with the investment indicator for Spain. It will merely stay an unused field unless it is explicitly repurposed in a custom extension.

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: 🔴 IT System Landscape Transparency with Open Resource Discovery (ORD)
entry.content:
Developers often face challenges understanding the IT system landscape: What systems exist, what services do they offer, and how can they be integrated? Open Resource Discovery (ORD) addresses this issue by providing an open-source standard for decentralized system descriptions. ORD details available APIs, events, data products, and AI resources, along with their contracts and documentation.

In this talk, we will explain what ORD is, the problems it solves, and why we created it. We will also discuss how SAP leverages ORD to publish a static catalog of offerings, enable real-time landscape introspection, and support products like SAP Business Technology Platform, SAP Business Data Cloud, and SAP Build.

Additionally, we will present how we have built an ecosystem to simplify ORD adoption, helping developers identify issues earlier and improve the quality of metadata and documentation over time for both SAP and our customers.

Finally, we will share our current thinking on how ORD can benefit the AI ecosystem.

entry.title: Instance Sharing - SAP Cloud Logging
entry.content:
Co-Authored by: @wolfgang_theilmann and @Benny-Goerzig 

Centralizing observability data offers significant advantages by providing a unified view across different organizations, spaces, sub-accounts, and even regions.

SAP Cloud Logging provides the ability to "share" a single instance across various application deployment locations. This offers two key benefits:

  • It simplifies the centralization of observability data into a single or fewer instances.
  • It drastically reduces costs compared to Application Logging, where customers must create a separate instance for each space.

This document outlines different contexts, tools, options, and best practices for instance sharing

Understanding scopes of sharing and tools

Sharing an instance basically involves either creating a new instance or reusing an existing one at a specific location and making it (credentials) available to multiple applications, spaces or other locations, without having to create a duplicate instance.

There are two primary methods of instance sharing:

Built-in / native sharing

In this approach, the runtime environment (such as Cloud Foundry) or platform (such as BTP) provides APIs to facilitate sharing.

  • Advantages:
    • Credentials are transparently transferred to the destination.
    • The system manages authorization, determining who can share or modify the parent instance.
    • The lifecycle of the parent and shared instance are closely aligned
  • Disadvantages:
    • This method limits shareability to a narrower location scope, such as within a single subaccount.

Documentation: CF docs on sharing-instance

Sharing by reusing credentials

Cloud Logging service offers global endpoints – which makes its APIs accessible from anywhere. So, create service key from an existing instance which can be used to create new  and consumed by applications from other location. Cloud Foundry offers “User Provided Service” to achieve this.

    • Advantages:
      • Universal applicability across regions, subaccounts, and environments.
    • Disadvantages:
      • Maintenance considerations, including credential transport and rotation, can be additional effort.

Documentation: User-Provided service instances

Locations of instance sharing

In BTP, instance sharing can happen between different source and destination locations. For this guide, we’ll zoom in on the Cloud Foundry runtime and walk through all the possible ways you can share an instance within it.

Cloud Foundry (CF) runtime

In CF environment, instance sharing can occur in the following scenarios

Same CF API endpoints:

CF spaces in the same org

  • Example: Space-A ⇆ Space-B within Org-X

CF spaces in different subaccounts on the same main/extension landscape and region

  • Example: Space-A in EU10-004 (SubAccount-X) ⇆ Space-B in EU10-004 (SubAccount-Y)
Different CF API endpoints:

CF Spaces across different subaccounts on different hyperscaler

  • Example: Space-A in EU10 (SubAccount-X) ⇆ Space-B in EU30 (SubAccount-Y)

CF Spaces across different subaccounts on different main/extension landscape

  • Example: Space-A in US10 (SubAccount-X) ⇆ Space-B in US10-002 (SubAccount-Y)

CF Spaces across different subaccounts in different regions

  • Example: Space-A in US10 (SubAccount-X) ⇆ Space-B in EU10

Sharing using CF CLI

Sharing a Cloud Logging instance using CF API, where possible, is straightforward.

cf share-service SERVICE-INSTANCE -s OTHER-SPACE

then proceed with binding it to CF apps from the OTHER-SPACE.

Please read the limitations and security considerations from CF docs on sharing-instance

Sharing using User-Provided Service (UPS)

Best Practices
  1. Name Service Keys Clearly
    • Consider using one service key per remote CF location where the instance will be shared.
    • Include the remote CF location identifier in the service key name for easy association with its target destination.
  2.  Rotate Service Keys Periodically
    • Either based on your organisation’s compliance policy or if you mTLS, then based on the cert validity, you might have to periodically update the User Provided service
    • Rotation involves creating a new service key in the parent instance and updating the UPS in the target locations accordingly.
Sample Script

Below is a sample script demonstrating how to share and update an instance using a User-Provided Service (UPS).

In this example, we create a central SAP Cloud Logging instance in EU10 (referred to as the Source CF location) and make it available in other location - EU30 (referred to as the Destination CF location) by sharing it through a User-Provided Service.

  • Create & bind to UPS:  See attachment below create-UPS.txt 📎
  • Update UPS: See attachment below update-UPS.txt 📎

Visualizing

Using OpenSearch Dashboards, telemetry data (CF logs & CF Container metrics) from all the bound apps can be viewed centrally from the parent instance.

You can distinguish and filter for different locations based on fields like `organization_name` and `organization_id`

Considerations & Tradeoffs

Planning actual instantiation and deployment of Cloud Logging service instances should consider the following aspects:

  • Cost: in most cases shared instances should be more cost effective than dedicated ones.
  • Legal/Operational aspects might enforce customers to run dedicated instances. Still Cloud Logging provides many security-level features (e.g. index-level security) which might be sufficient to satisfy those.
  • Analytics: putting observability data into a shared instances allows for combined analysis. Note: in contrast to Application Logging, data cannot be analyzed across service instances.
  • Ingestion throughput: Remote ingestion (from Cloud Foundry) may come with bit lower throughput especially if you connect regions that far away physically.

entry.title: Re: SAP S4 HANA Cloud - oAuth 2.0 with Scopes
entry.content:
Hello @Simon 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, the outbound OAuth 2.0 configured in a Communication System supports the client-credentials grant with Audience/Resource, but it does not expose a field for OAuth scopes. That’s why you don’t see it in the UI.

Use the Azure AD v1 token endpoint (resource-based)

    •  Token endpoint: https://login.microsoftonline.com/<tenant>/oauth2/token (v1)
    •  Use your API’s Application ID URI as the Audience in S/4HANA Cloud.
    • With v1, Azure requires a resource (not a scope), which matches S/4HANA Cloud’s Audience field.
    • Grant your calling app Application permissions for that API and consent to them in Azure AD.
    • This removes the need to send the scope.

If you must use v2 (scope-based)

    •  Azure v2 expects scope=api://<app-id>/.default for client-credentials.
    • ◦ The Communication System UI cannot send scope, so use SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Integration) or SAP BTP Destinations, where you can configure OAuth2 client-credentials and explicitly set the scope, then call Power Platform from there.

Why FB60-type fields are not useful in this context. The Outbound OAuth 2.0 block you showed (Authorisation Endpoint, Token Endpoint, Audience, mTLS Endpoint) is the complete set for S/4HANA Cloud direct outbound. There is no hidden switch for scopes at present.

Practical setup (recommended approach)

  •  Prefer Azure v1 token endpoint plus Audience (resource) in S/4HANA Cloud, or
  •  Insert SAP Cloud Integration in the middle if your security team mandates v2 plus scopes.

Check the documentation below

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity-platform/v2-oauth2-client-creds-grant-flow

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity-platform/v2-overview

Configuring the OAuth 2.0 Client-SAP Help 

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Outbound Delivery Date
entry.content:
To answer your first question, SAP creates outbound deliveries based on the confirmed delivery date in the sales order, which is typically determined by the ATP check at order entry. Even if stock becomes available earlier from a different PO (like PO 3850), SAP does not automatically reschedule the delivery date unless:

  • You manually change the delivery date
  • You re-run ATP or delivery scheduling
  • You implement custom logic to override the original date

So, even though stock was available on 04/06/2025, the system retained the original confirmed date of 01/07/2025 from PO 4627 because that was the date promised to the customer and used for scheduling.

To answer your second question, in standard SAP behavior, Delivery creation is triggered by stock availability, but Delivery dates are not automatically recalculated based on that availability unless explicitly configured

This means the system creates the delivery when stock is available, but it does not override the original delivery date. This is to preserve the customer commitment and avoid unintended early shipments

If your business wants deliveries to reflect actual stock availability, you’ll need to enable dynamic delivery scheduling or use a custom enhancement (e.g., in delivery creation logic or via BAdI) to update the delivery date to the current date when stock is available

entry.title: Work Zone: text widgets in a single row, height no longer aligns
entry.content:
Work Zone has once again unilaterally changed the way it behaves with the result of messing up my design.

Until this morning (13 Aug 25) when adding text widgets to a single row (a freestyle section with multiple columns), text widgets were presented as the same height, regardless of how much text was in each.

See example, below: each of the three elements has a different amount of text (2 lines, 3 lines, 1 line), but the white boxes all displayed with the same height as the largest box.

Perfect - a nice balanced design.

Now here's what it looks like:

The text widget height is controlled by the amount of text in each widget. My design looks like a row of wonky teeth. Thanks SAP.

So what has happened and why? When are we going to get consulted or at the very least notified in advance of these sorts of changes? See my other posts for other rants about SAP changing the front end unilaterally. 

Honestly SAP, you are consistently disappointing. If you expect us to promote your product in any way you need to get better at this.

entry.title: Re: How to Set Up Automatic Login in SAP
entry.content:
Hi @Aprendiz_Tecnologia 

Thank you for your question. Let us look at potential solutions.

There are a few options you can consider to enable you achieve the desired automation. You can either choose SAP Shortcut (sapshcut.exe), SAP GUI Scripting, Auto Logon File, Single Sign-On (this is most secure method) or third part tools.

However, I would recommend you prioritize use sapshcut.exe or GUI scripting, which provides you a quick local setup or you implement SSO for more security and compliance.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Advance Your Career as a Certified SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Project Manager
entry.content:
Around 60% of cloud buyers told IDC’s Cloud Pulse Survey in October 2024 that their business’ IT or digital infrastructure currently requires major transformation, and 82% said their cloud also requires modernization. In response to these pressing industry needs, effective project management has become essential, particularly for navigating complex cloud-based initiatives. The new certification for SAP Certified Associate - Managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects (C_S4PM2) provides a unique opportunity for professionals to become certified project managers, equipping them to lead transformative digital efforts with expertise and strategic insight. 

Designed for Project Managers, Consultants, and Technical Leads, this certification empowers you to excel in managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations, positioning you to become a strategic leader in your organization's digital strategy, providing direction and specialist knowledge in project execution. 

How to prepare for this certification 

You can prepare for the exam in your own pace, by completing the "Managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects" learning journey, designed to provide comprehensive insight into SAP S/4HANA Cloud project management. With free access to the learning journey, you can deepen your expertise of managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition projects, spotlighting SAP tools and strategic implementation methodologies. Among these, the RISE with SAP Methodology stands out as a vital, holistic approach tailored for cloud transformation journeys. 

Additionally, SAP Community blog posts provide some supporting information to deepen your understanding and preparation: 

  • 12 Things that SAP implementation methodology SAP Activate tells you to do 
  • Planning your System Conversion to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition following SAP Activate 
  • SAP Activate for RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition now available by Deployment Journey 
  • Conversion Guide for SAP S/4HANA 2023 for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023
  • Review the SAP Activate Minute videos in this playlist. 

You can also explore more insights about SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition on SAP for Me, and take a look at the release notes.  

As a prerequisite, candidates should possess project management experience, preferably in ERP implementation, especially SAP Cloud-related projects. Additionally, hands-on experience with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition solutions, knowledge of SAP Cloud ALM, and experience managing cloud-based SAP projects are beneficial.

Get started today 

Achieving the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition certification allows you to become a crucial asset in driving your organization's growth and innovation. This certification validates your 

competency in integrating business goals with technical solutions, enhancing your leadership role in cloud project management.  

Certified learners must regularly update their skills and keep certifications valid by completing mandatory annual assessments before expiration. With an SAP Learning Hub subscription, you can take these assessments anytime during your certification's validity.  

Build the skills you need on the SAP Learning site and get inspired by reading learner stories on SAP Community, ask questions and connect with fellow learners. When you’re ready, take your certification exam and start shaping your industry's future!

entry.title: Re: how can i restrict the equipment that can be seen by...
entry.content:
Hi @Hichem_Rahmani 

Thank you for your question. Note sure this request is still open on your side.

Following up on the issue you raised regarding the difference in behaviour, this appears to be due to different filtering logic in the two apps. To re-iterate the important details:

Find Technical Object applies stricter filtering based only on cost center, so objects with an empty cost center field are excluded.

Change Technical Object may retrieve the equipment via direct reference, bypassing the stricter cost center filter.

Here are steps I suggest you take to ensure the settings are correctly done:

First, verify the cost center restriction behaviour for empty fields in the “Find Technical Object” app.

Then check if the restriction can be adjusted to also consider WBS elements in equipment visibility.

Finally, review SAP Help or SAP Notes for known limitations in this area, and if needed, you can raise a ticket with SAP Support to confirm if this is expected behaviour or a defect. The link below will be helpful

 

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

 

https://help.sap.com/doc/7c9e0bbbd1664c2581b2038a1c7ae4b3/2508.500/en-US/FSD_CE2508.pdf

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/using-restrictions-to-enhance-user-authorizations-in-the-sap-s-4hana-cloud/ba-p/13575978

entry.title: Re: How to monitor the HANA DB Encryption status for the...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

In SAP Focused RUN, the HANA DB General Encryption Status information is collected exclusively in the Configuration & Security Analysis (CSA) application.
There is a CSA store called HANA Encryption (HDB_ENCRYPTION) that provides information regarding Backup, Log, and Persistence scopes.

If you want to monitor this information, you can create a CSA policy for it and even create a custom metric to monitor the results.

For more information regarding CSA policies and Custom Metric creation, please refer to the following documentation:

  • SAP Expert Portal - Configuration & Security Analysis
  • SAP Expert Portal - Syntax Rules and Policy Check Examples
  • SAP Expert Portal - Available CCDB Config Stores
  • KBA: 3197989 - How to use Configuration and Security Analytics in System Monitoring Alerting - SAP Focused RUN



Best regards,
Jessica
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: How to generate Payment advise if payment done by app...
entry.content:
Hello @gautam_SAP 

Here is the E2E process for generating and printing a Payment Advice in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public when you post a payment manually:

Create the Payment Advice Manually

  1. Open Manage Payment Advice.
  2. Click Add Manually.
  3. Fill in:
    • Company Code
    • Payment Advice Type = 04 (Manual entry)
    • Payment Amount and Currency
    • Reference to Journal Entry from Post Outgoing Payments
  4. Save — you should now see it in the list (as per your screenshot).

Assign a Form Template in Output Parameter Determination (OPD)

  1. Open Output Parameter Determination (OPD) app.
  2. Select Billing Document → Change to Payment Advice in “Show Rules for”.
  3. In Form Template decision table (DT_FORM_TEMPLATE), add/maintain:
    • Output Type = PAYMENT_ADVICE
    • Form Template = your PDF layout (e.g., YY1_PAYMENT_ADVICE)
    • Channel = Print / Email (depending on requirement)

Activate the rule.

Trigger Output for the Payment Advice

  1. Go back to Manage Payment Advices.
  2. Select the payment advice → Open it.
  3. Go to Output Items tab.
  4. Click Send Output (or Trigger Output).

Print or Download

  • If the output channel is Print, the job appears in the output queue.
  • If it’s Email, it’s sent to the maintained recipient.
  • You can preview or download the PDF from Output Items → Display PDF.

Common Issues:

  • If the Output Items tab is missing, the payment advice type is not configured in OPD.
  • If the PDF doesn’t appear, check:
    • Form template assignment in OPD.
    • That the user has access to the output channel.
    • Application Log for output determination errors.

Output Parameter Determination 

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Implementing an Average to Actuals Strategy for Scope 3.1
entry.content:
Companies often begin their Scope 3.1 carbon emissions accounting with a spend-based approach, as aggregated spend data by purchase category is typically readily available from procurement systems. This method generally meets the needs of initial voluntary reporting and hotspot analysis. However, with the rise of mandatory reporting requirements, carbon taxes, and increasing demands from business-to-business customers for product-level carbon equivalent calculations, the spend-based approach is increasingly insufficient. A more granular methodology is now required to achieve higher accuracy. Effective carbon reduction strategies require not only greater accuracy but also more frequent emissions calculations, as the carbon footprints of materials in a supply chain can change throughout the year. This document outlines how companies can leverage SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to transition from annual, average-based calculations to a more granular, frequent, and ultimately more accurate emissions accounting methodology. While the example focuses on purchased materials, the same approach can be applied to other scope categories as well.

Carbon Footprint Equivalent Calculations: Specificity,  Granularity, and Frequency

The Greenhouse  Gas Protocol [1] allows for multiple methods to calculate the carbon footprint of purchased goods. Today, most companies rely on spend-based calculations, which are inherently imprecise. Because these calculations are tied to monetary value, changes in pricing can affect the reported footprint even when the actual environmental impact remains unchanged. Moreover, spend-based data are typically aggregated at the product group or category level, offering only average values rather than material-specific emissions.

Transitioning from a spend-based approach to a more specific, quantity-based method using Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) databases (e.g., ecoinvent [2], CarbonMinds [3]) enhances the accuracy of carbon footprint calculations. This increased precision enables more targeted and effective decarbonization measures. However, it's important to note that such average data may not reflect supplier-specific conditions. Therefore, supplier-specific carbon footprint data for procured products is considered the most specific and, thus, the most accurate source and should be prioritized whenever available.

The second dimension is the granularity of the activity data [4,5], indicating whether it reflects individual business transactions or is derived from aggregated data, such as at the product group or category level. For example, aggregating the purchases of all products falling within a specific product category into a single total amount spent is the simplest approach, yet also the least accurate, since the corresponding emission factor applies to the entire category and is based on an average. Additionally, business transactions such as goods receipts and returns may be combined into a single business activity. Alternatively, a more precise, transaction-based approach would look at each business transaction by product and supplier. For example, each product purchase is evaluated separately by the supplier, and returns are assessed individually rather than netted against receipts. Such an approach would require a deep integration into the underlying ERP system to gather the relevant business transaction documents and ensure the highest accuracy, as the same data is also used for financial accounting purposes.

Finally, many companies currently calculate the carbon footprint of purchased materials (Scope 3.1) on an annual basis, aggregating over a period of 12 months, to meet external reporting requirements such as the CSRD. However, to effectively decarbonize procurement and logistics processes, more frequent calculations are needed. Increasing the frequency from yearly to quarterly or even monthly enables companies to assess, in near real-time, the effectiveness of both their own and their supply chain partners’ decarbonization initiatives, allowing them to take corrective actions when necessary. This is critical not only for regulatory compliance but also to address the growing demands of customers and end-consumers for sustainability information and reduction targets.


The above graph illustrates the key dimensions of improving the accuracy of corporate and product carbon footprint calculations. A company may begin with an annual, spend, and activity-based calculation, for example, estimating the carbon footprint of plastics based on annual spend. From this starting point, the company can enhance its approach by increasing the calculation frequency to quarterly. Simultaneously, or as a subsequent step, the company may shift to a transaction-based approach, leveraging the data provided in the individual business transactions. In parallel, some suppliers may already be able to provide product-specific carbon equivalent data for high-impact or high-value products. Incorporating these supplier-provided (assumed as primary) emission factors [4] can further improve the accuracy of carbon footprint calculations.
 
In the following steps, we will outline how a customer can use SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to transition from a yearly, activity- and spend-based calculation process for Scope 3.1 emissions to more accurate and granular methodologies, without the risk of double-counting. A general scenario guide can also be found in the SAP help documentation [6].
 
Our scenario involves a single plant (CB_PL1) and two products (CB_Cotton and CB_Color), sourced from a single supplier (CB_Supplier). We will demonstrate varying levels of calculation accuracy, starting with average spend-based estimations using activity forms, and progressing to supplier-specific, transaction-based calculations. A key focus will be ensuring that emissions are not double-counted when improving accuracy for only a subset of products.
 
In real-world scenarios, transitioning from average values to actuals might take place over several months. Since this paper cannot reflect a real-time timeline, we simulate this transition by changing the configuration within the same month and re-running the calculations accordingly. Please note that the emission factors used are illustrative sample data, selected for simplicity.
 
This paper focuses exclusively on the calculation process and the transition from spend-based averages to actuals, highlighting how SAP Sustainability Footprint Management supports this objective. From a reporting perspective, each of the transition steps described might require a re-baselining of carbon emission reporting metrics.

 

Step 1: Monthly, activity, and spend-based calculation

In this step, as shown by the diagram below, we are using the most common, but also most inaccurate method to calculate scope 3.1 emissions. We perform a spend-based calculation based on the total amount spent on purchased products for plant CB. We can easily choose between yearly, quarterly, or monthly calculations by selecting the right periodicity. We will choose monthly for the remainder of this simulation.

When setting up the Sustainability Footprint Management form for business activity data collection (the amount spent), we are defining the average CO2e emission factor for products purchased by this plant per Euro spent. In this case, 1kg CO2e/EUR.

In the next step, we will collect the monthly amount spent on materials purchased at the plant. We assume a total spent of 11000 Euro, covering both products, CB_Cotton and CB_Color. This results in 11000kg = 11Ton CO2e.

Note, in the Sustainability Footprint Management scope definition template for calculating the emission footprint, no value steps are included. Only the Business Activities form for GHG emissions is active (last line).

Below is the Corporate Carbon Footprint Overview, showing Scope 3.1 of 11 tons CO2e.

The following screenshot shows the details of the calculation. The formula multiplies the 11000Euro with the emission factor of 1 kg/Euro = 0.001 Ton/Euro. The calculation can be reviewed below:

 

Step 2: Transaction-based calculation

In this step, we transition from an activity-based calculation to a transaction-based approach. While we continue to use Euro spend as the basis, we no longer collect spending data manually via forms. Instead, we integrate directly with the ERP backend system and use material documents related to goods receipts to retrieve the spend amount for each purchase. Data can be collected on a monthly, quarterly, or yearly basis; for consistency, we maintain the same monthly granularity used previously.

 

Below is the adjusted scope template. Selecting the product acquisition option in the value chain steps and deactivating the business activities for scope 3.1 will prevent double-counting.

 

The next step is to define the spend-based emission factors for all products. In this example, we have two products: CB_Cotton and CB_Color. The calculation method remains spend-based, and as in the previous example, we apply a uniform emission factor of 1kg CO2e per 1 Euro spent to each of the products. The screenshot below shows the assignment of the emission factor to the CB_Cotton product.

Unlike in Step 1, we do not use the business activity template to load the total amount spent. Instead, we rely on the more granular, actual business transactions, such as goods receipts, returns, etc., for the respective month. As shown below, based on the goods receipt documents, we purchased EUR 9,000 of CB_Cotton and EUR 2,000 of CB_Color, totaling EUR 11,000, which is the same amount as in the previous step.

Below is the result of the calculation: a total of 11 tons of Scope 3.1 emissions. We applied the same spend-based average emission factor of 1 kg CO2e per Euro across all purchases, and therefore, the result is the same as in the Step 1 calculations. However, the table below the diagram breaks down the contribution of each purchase to the overall emissions.

Since in SAP ERP the material documents contain the amount spent per product, we have detailed data on how much was spent on each purchased material. This allows us to define more precise emission factors. In the example below, we adjust the emission factor for the CB_Color product from 1 ton to 0.5 tons of CO2e per Euro.

The result of the calculation run is shown below. The total Scope 3.1 footprint for plant CB is now 10 tons. Unlike the activity-based calculation, this approach provides visibility into how the plant’s footprint is distributed across different components, in this case, the two purchased products. CB_Cotton contributes 9 tons, while CB_Color contributes 1 ton to the total footprint. Although still based on spend, the higher granularity of transaction-based data allows for applying product-specific emission factors and improves the accuracy of the overall footprint calculation.

Below are the two spend-based calculations. For CB_Cotton, the 9000 Euro spent on purchases results in 9 tons of CO2e, and for CB_Color, the 2000 Euro spent results in 1Ton of CO2e.

In summary, to transition incrementally from a form-based to a more granular transaction–based calculation, we recommend applying the transaction–based approach to the entire plant, using spend-based emission factors first, to maintain consistency.

A key takeaway is that this transaction–based method allows for the use of different spend-based emission factors for each product, demonstrating how transaction-based calculations enhance accuracy.

In the next step, we will further improve accuracy by introducing quantity-based emission factors.

Step 3: From Spend-based to Quantity-based

Customers may not have quantity-based emission factors available for all purchased materials within a plant. Therefore, in Step 3, we will continue using a spend-based emission factor for one product, while applying a quantity-based emission factor, sourced from an LCA database, for the other.

In this step, we will simulate a quantity-based approach for CB_Cotton, increasing the specificity of the emission factor, while retaining the spend-based emission factor of 0.5 tons CO2e per Euro for CB_Color.

Below is the new emission factor assignment for CB_Cotton can be seen. We created an emission factor entry into the LCA database template for a product classified as HS-620442.  The same classification can be found in the CB_Cotton product master data record (not shown here). The Sustainability Footprint Management AI mapping function (a feature of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management) found a medium similarity (see similarity score 7.58 below) between these entries, and we confirmed the mapping. The result can be seen below, where the emission factor for CB_Cotton got changed from a spend-based emission factor to an average quantity-based factor of 0.009 kg CO2e per kg of cotton. [7]

 

As in the previous calculation, we use business transaction data as the basis for the calculation. Below are the two purchase transactions considered: we purchased 1,000,000 kg of CB_Cotton and 1,000 liters of CB_Color, spending EUR 2,000 on the color.

As described above, we apply a quantity-based emission factor for CB_Cotton, while continuing to use the previous spend-based emission factor for CB_Color.

In the Sankey diagram below, the total 3.1 emissions remain at 10 tons, with 9 tons from cotton and 1 Ton from the color. So far, there is no change.

If compared to the former step, the calculation differs for the cotton. The calculation is not based on the Euro spent anymore. Instead, it used the purchased quantity (1.000.000 kg) and multiplied this by the new emission factor of 0.009 kg CO2e/kg, which we derived from the LCA database. The calculation details can be seen below.

For the color, the calculation remains the same, as can be seen below. It uses a spent-based emission factor of 0.5 kg per Euro spent for color.

 

Step 4: Using supplier-specific emission factors

In the final step, we will further enhance the specificity of the emission factors, aiming for even higher accuracy of the calculation. Up to this point, the emission factors used were average values, either spend-based or based on product classification. The next step involves using product-specific and product–supplier-specific emission factors, which will significantly improve the accuracy of the calculation.

The cotton was supplied by CB_Supplier. If the supplier provides emission factors, such as via the SAP Sustainability Data Exchange [8] using the PACT [9] protocol, these are treated as more reliable primary data. In this case, we assume the supplier has provided a slightly lower emission factor of 0.0085 kgCO2e/kg than the 0.009 kgCO2e/kg obtained from the LCA database.

Below, you can see both the product classification–based emission factor and the supplier-provided emission factor for CB_Cotton, both with the same validity period. The system prioritizes the supplier-provided emission factor, as it is considered more specific. If the same product is sourced from multiple suppliers, the system will apply the classification-based emission factor to those purchases where the supplier has not provided specific data. This feature will prevent double-counting as individual transactions are calculated separately with the most specific emission factor available.

For simplicity, we will retain the spend-based emission factor for CB_Color. However, it’s easy to see how this approach could also be applied to CB_Color using supplier-specific data.

Below is the result of the calculation. The total carbon footprint of purchased products during the period is 9.5 tons, consisting of 1 ton from CB_Color and 8.5 tons from CB_Cotton. This is slightly lower than in previous calculations due to the reduced, supplier-specific emission factor of 0.0085 kg CO2e per kg.

The detailed calculation for the purchased CB_Cotton is shown below.

Conclusion

In this article, we presented a method for transitioning from traditional spend-based Scope 3.1 calculations to more accurate, transaction-level, and quantity-based carbon footprint calculations. We outlined three key steps in the process:

  1. Shifting from an overall activity-based approach to a transaction-based calculation
  2. Enhancing accuracy by shifting from spend-based calculation to quantity-based emission calculation
  3. Further refining the results with vendor-specific primary emission factors.

This transition does not need to happen all at once, as detailed data may not be available for every product or category. Instead, we demonstrated how a gradual, step-by-step approach can improve accuracy over time, while avoiding double-counting.

SAP customers often begin using Sustainability Footprint Management in a productive pilot environment, leveraging actual production data to evaluate the accuracy improvements described above. The results are then reviewed with key customers who request product footprint data, helping to identify and prioritize future investments in supplier collaboration on primary data and further decarbonization efforts.

References:

[1] https://ghgprotocol.org/

[2] https://ecoinvent.org/

[3] https://www.carbon-minds.com

[4] https://docs.carbon-transparency.org/ref/methodology/pact-methodology-v3.0.pdf p.59ff 

[5] Here, we define activity-based as a method that potentially combines multiple business transactions into a single activity, for example, merging goods receipts and returns into a unified purchasing activity. This terminology aligns with the concept of business activity as used in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. https://help.sap.com/docs/sustainability-footprint-management/application-help-for-corporate-and-products/using-manage-business-activities-application?q=activity

[6]https://help.sap.com/docs/sustainability-footprint-management/scenario-guide-for-sap-sustainability-footprint-management-93545a51dfb84c228a636b9d01c23707/process-4-calculating-scope-3-1-emissions-using-average-data-and-spend-based-purchased-product-footp 

[7] Note that for the system to use the new emission factor, the validity of the former emission factor might have to be changed.

[8] Sustainability Data Exchange enables businesses to request, collect, and share standardized, accurate product carbon footprint data across the value chain to support compliance, integration, and actionable climate insights.https://www.sap.com/products/business-network/sustainability-data-exchange.html

[9] https://docs.carbon-transparency.org/ref/methodology/pact-methodology-v3.0.pdf p.59ff

entry.title: Re: Restricting changes in Budget or Notifications
entry.content:
Hello @adnanmaqbool 

There’s no standard approval workflow for changes to a released budget in CO or PS in the S4HANA Public Cloud. Changes take effect immediately if the user has edit rights.

To control this, you can:

  • Restrict budget edit authorisations after release.
  • Use Situation Handling or Business Event Handling to trigger alerts/workflows on budget changes.
  • Monitor via budget reports for audit.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: XML Nómina concepto exento y gravado
entry.content:
Hola comunidad, ¿qué tal?

Recientemente realizamos la actualización a EHP8 y, al revisar la generación del XML con la transacción PC00_M32_CFDIM seleccionando la agrupación por CC-nómina, observamos que se está reemplazando el concepto que debería mostrarse en el XML.



En RT tengo el concepto pagado 1471 y el concepto exento /42F



En T596J, en aplicación parcial CFDP, el concepto 1471 tiene la clave 029P y /42F tiene la clave 029E.


Al generarme el detalle de la percepción, la línea queda cambiando el concepto 1471 por el exento:



Anteriormente, el comportamiento que tenía era que siempre se mostraba el concepto configurado en 029P y el 029E se usaba únicamente para descontar la parte exenta y aplicar lo que correspondía para cada atributo del XML, pero sin cambiar la clave de lo que se mostraba.

Actualmente, después de la actualización, la clave se está reemplazando, y está ocurriendo algo similar con los conceptos de prima vacacional y aguinaldo.

Quedo a espera de sus comentarios y/o sugerencias, agradeciendo de antemano su tiempo, saludos cordiales.

entry.title: Re: How to Integrate E-Invoice India in sap public cloud...
entry.content:
Dear @Sanjay_BS1 

After completing the initial setup and integration for SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC), public cloud edition, and connecting your third-party e-invoicing provider (Excellon), the next steps for India compliance primarily involve configuring document types, mappings, and monitoring processes to ensure legally valid invoice exchanges.

Typical next steps to follow:

Define Country/Region-Specific Parameters

  • In the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, go to Define Parameters for Electronic Document Processing.
  • Maintain India-specific settings for GST, IRN generation, and any QR code requirements.

Map Source Documents to Electronic Document Types

  • Use the Assign Document Type configuration to map your billing documents to the correct eDocument type for India.
  • Ensure you use the correct scenario for B2B/B2G invoices.

Configure Communication with Excellon

  • Set up the outbound interface format according to Excellon’s API specification (JSON/XML).
  • Ensure required GSTN fields (GSTIN, HSN code, IRN) are populated in your billing data.

Test End-to-End Flow

  • Create sample invoices in S/4HANA Cloud, trigger eDocument creation, and verify Excellon receives and processes them successfully.
  • Confirm the IRN and QR code are returned and stored in the invoice.

Enable Monitoring and Error Handling

  • Use eDocument Cockpit for real-time status tracking.
  • Set up alerts or Situation Handling for failed submissions.

User Training & Go-Live Readiness

  • Train finance/AP teams on monitoring and reprocessing steps.
  • Validate that test invoices pass GSTN compliance checks before live rollout.

Best practices:

  • Always test in your quality tenant before moving to production.
  • Keep an eye on GSTN API updates, India e-invoicing rules can change frequently.
  • Use the SAP-provided India eDocument format as a baseline to reduce maintenance.

Let me know if you need further assistance

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: We have a requirement for Digital Signature on Public...
entry.content:
Hello @aakash96 

In the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (India)

  • GST e-invoicing – Digital signatures are applied by the GSTN via your e-invoicing provider; SAP stores and prints the IRN/QR code.
  • Company-side PDF signing – Not available natively; use Output Management to route PDFs to a third-party signing tool or middleware.

3513669 - GST India: Deprecation of Digital Compliance Service for India

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: HCM Brasil - eSocial - Evento S-1010 - Extensão licença maternidade devido ao Zika vírus
entry.content:
Olá pessoal, 

Para atender à nova Lei 15.156/2025, que trata da extensão da licença maternidade, foi disponibilizada uma atualização na solução de folha de pagamento. A mudança inclui novas rubricas técnicas e um novo customizing essencial para a geração correta das informações para o eSocial. 

A atualização cria as seguintes rubricas técnicas para o tratamento dos valores referentes à extensão da licença maternidade: 

  • /T92 - Extensão Matern - Mensal 
  • /T93 - Extensão Matern - Medias 
  • /T94 - Extensão Matern - Horas 

Além disso, para garantir uma declaração correta ao governo, foi criada a nova subaplicação SOCM (Códigos de incidência de INSS Maternidade) para a view  V_T596J. 

Nela, você precisa cadastrar as rubricas de salário-maternidade e o Código de incidência de INSS (codIncCP) relacionado. 

Exemplo: 

Código de INSS 

Rubrica 

21 

/T92 

... 

... 

Importante:  

É fundamental que  todas as rubricas de salário-maternidade (tanto as novas quanto as já existentes no sistema) sejam cadastradas na view V_T596J com a subaplicação SOCM. 

Por quê?  Ao realizar este cadastro, você evita que o sistema gere eventos S-1010 (Tabela de Rubricas) que já estão aceitos pelo governo e que não sofreram alterações, garantindo a consistência e a integridade dos dados enviados ao governo. 

A solução está disponível através das seguintes SAP Notes: 

  • 3637728 - Law 15.156/2025 - New wage types for maternity leave extensions for congenital Zika syndrome 
  • 3638824 - eSocial - S-1010 - Customizing to inform inss code for maternity wage types 

Por fim, para garantir que a folha de pagamento funcione corretamente com a nova extensão de licença maternidade, é necessário configurar um novo subtipo para o infotipo 2001 (Ausência). Mais informações sobre a configuração estão disponíveis na SAP Note 3641684 - Law 15.156/2025 - Congenital Zika Virus maternity leave extension payroll configuration.

Gostou desse post? Dê um Like e compartilhe o conteúdo com seus colegas.    

 

Fiquem à vontade para deixar um feedback, comentário ou pergunta sobre este Blog post no espaço abaixo. E não esqueçam de seguir a tag HCM Payroll Brazil na SAP Community para ficarem ligados nas últimas notícias.  

Um abraço,  

Gabriel Pereira

entry.title: inventory transition plan from company code to company code
entry.content:
Looking for suggestions on how to manage inventory in the following scenario :

Background:

Portion of Company Code 1234 is transitioning to Company Code 0987. 

There are open PO's that have inbound deliveries created against company code A and want to prematurely receive the stock in under Company code 1234, but want to restrict it for use for sales or production. which movement type is best that we can easily move to after doing a migo 101 on the inbound delivery. The transition plan would be to create the stock in company code 0987 in that same status and do a movement type to 101. Unfortunately we cannot move it to 341, block stock as it may interfere with existing material batch status. 


Please provide  options, t-codes and goods movements that would allow me to transfer the inventory to a different stock type?  Please note these are batched managed materials.

entry.title: Simple Signavio Question about Audiences and One about SSO
entry.content:
Several business units use Signavio at my company.  Right now, there is only one Audience (General).  There are many user groups, but none are tied to Audiences.

I would like to create an Audience tied to a user group populated with members of my business unit so that I can customize the view of different elements within Collaboration Hub- Fact Sheet, etc.

If I create an Audience and tie it to a group of users in my business unit, will the other users who are only members of the General Audience continue to see the Collaboration Hub as they do now?  Or, if I set up one Audience tied to a user group, does that mean everyone has to be in a specific audience?

Another question about SSO:  I noticed that the idP can send user group  names for Just in Time provisioning so that someone can get automatically added to a user group.  Has anyone ever set up logic to tie user groups to business units so that the IdP sends the user group specific to that person's business unit?  That would be ideal and would prevent me from having to come after the fact and add new users to a User Group tied to my business unit's Audience.

thank you!

entry.title: Re: Behavior of CPI's message header/property in a multicast
entry.content: The multicast EIP will copy the source exchange and multicast each copy. However, the copy is a shallow copy, so in case you have mutable message bodies, then any changes will be visible by the other copied messages.

entry.title: In S/4 Public Cloud with function substitutes the program RFWT0010 ?
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are facing the problem below with  withholding tax in Cloud Public . in SAP ECC we have the program RFWT0010 that corrects the open items and we can go on with the daily activities 

How can we correct the open itens in Public Cloud to continue working ?

Thanks

Lilian Margonari

 

1 items have not been activated due to inconsistent withholding tax info

Message no. F5787

Diagnosis

The open items display different withholding tax information from the relevant business partner master record. For example, the number of withholding tax types in the open item could differ from the number of withholding tax types in the master record.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition - Define number range
entry.content:
Hello @Melissa_Pineda 

In the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, number range configuration is performed per business object via SSCUIs in Manage Your Solution. There is no single list from SAP, so search for number ranges in your tenant to view all IDs.

For example:

  • Materials: 100057 (Material Master), 100065/100066 (Purchasing)
  • Finance: 101101 (Document No. by Company Code), 101126 (Asset Master)
  • Sales: 102588 (Sales Orders), 102611 (Billing)
  • Production/Maintenance: 104159 (Production Orders), 104005 (Maintenance Notifications)

Check below SAP Documentation

SAP Help – SSCUI List for S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition

2754127 - How to find SSCUI configuration

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Breaking the Silos:Orchestrate end to end Characteristics Based Plans across IBP, ePPDS and S4HANA
entry.content:
This is a second blog in the series where I explore and update the latest in advanced supply planning in SAP IBP.  Here is a link to the first blog intro blog in this series. If you have not taken a look I highly encourage you to do so.  

https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-sap/unlock-the-potential-of-characteristics-based-planning-cbp-in-sap-ibp/ba-p/13786509 

Blog 2 Intro:

Planners have long dreamed of an uninterrupted flow from proactive attribute-level planning to flawless execution. Now it’s here. The  latest Characteristics-Based Planning (CBP) in IBP seamlessly orchestrates plans through S/4HANA Segmentation into ePPDS (CDP) — all out of the box — from strategic / tactical planning to detailed scheduling and execution. All Natively integrated. No workarounds. No data loss. 

From Plan to Production – Attribute-Driven Orchestration Now Out of the Box

Characteristics-Based Planning (CBP) in SAP IBP already empowers planners to manage supply and demand at a granular, attribute level including product and supply chain segments.

We now take this to the next level: CBP plans in IBP can now flow seamlessly through S/4HANA demand supply Segmentation into detailed planning and scheduling in S4HANA Manufacturing planning (ePPDS) running with CDP (characteristics dependent planning) — natively, out of the box!

This is not just integration — it’s end-to-end orchestration. Attributes like version, quality grade, or supply chain segment stay intact from tactical planning to shop floor execution, eliminating manual mapping, reducing errors, and ensuring planning intent is preserved in production. The result? Faster responses to demand changes, optimized sequencing, and execution without translation gaps.

here is an overview of the linked process. 

This is CBP without boundaries — one seamless flow, one process, one truth, from plan to production. It’s the kind of end-to-end precision that changes how supply chains run.

What’s Next
We’re exploring how to extend this orchestration to industries with more complex needs — Future scenarios could include shelf life–driven planning in conjunction with attribute-based component alignment for regulatory-compliant needs, all running seamlessly from IBP to execution. All this also intended on our latest Harmonised planning platform. 

Follow this space for more as we strive to bring the same proactive planning and seamless flows to some of the most regulated and quality-sensitive supply chains in the world. 

SAP Integrated Business Planning SAP Supply Chain Management

entry.title: Having Trouble Finding or Posting a Blog for SAP Activate? Start Here!
entry.content:
Hi SAP Activate community members. I have had several questions related to finding and creating blog content on the SAP Activate community, so I have provides some tips. Please forward this page link to any colleagues or friends that are having trouble with the finding or creating blogs in the community.

Finding the SAP Activate Community

SAP Activate community can be easily found different ways:

  1. The easiest method of getting to the SAP Activate community is by bookmarking the following link:  https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/activate. This does require that you remember where you stored your bookmark.
  2. My frequently used method is to use a search engine and the term ‘SAP Activate community’.

Find Blogs about SAP Activate

SAP Activate users and experts share their experiences with the community via blogs. We highlight several blogs in the SAP Activate community home page, but for a complete list follow the guidance below:

1.  Select ‘Products and Technology’, then ‘All Blogs’.

2. Select category ‘Managed tags’ then search for ‘SAP Activate’. The result will be a list of SAP Activate posts including Blogs, Q&A and other categories.

3.  Select ‘Blog Posts’ to view only Blogs.

Here is the direct link to SAP Activate Posts.  Make sure that you ‘Subscribe’ to the board.

Creating a Blog related to SAP Activate

Sharing with the community is fun and educational. It allows for you to connect directly to other members providing diverse perspectives on various topics. To create a blog related to SAP Activate, follow these steps:

  1. While on the ‘SAP Activate’ page, press the ‘Create a Post’ button. Note that you must be logged in to post.

2. Skip the Subject line and in the Location field, select Board ‘Enterprise Resource Planning Blogs’. This is the area that SAP Activate is assigned to.

3.  A new window will open, and you will be able to create and edit your blog.

4.  Assign the blog to the SAP Managed Tag of ‘SAP Activate’ if not defaulted. This will help other community member find the SAP Activate Blogs.

5.  Select a Blog Label that most fits the purpose.

6.  Create the blog text

7.  Save and Post. Note that posts from new bloggers will need to go through moderation before they're published.

I hope that this helps. Please provide your feedback in the ‘Comments’ below. 

Dan Ciecko - SAP Activate Product Management

entry.title: \/CPMB/LOAD_INFOPROV_UI - Error obtaining concurrency lock (foreign_lock)
entry.content:
With reference to Incident 676338/2025:

Currently, we are experiencing performance issues when submitting data to the BPC system due to high data volume.

SAP Max Attention onboarded in May and recommended adjusting the RECLEVLEL_NR parameter to values such as 20,000, 50,000, 70,000, or 100,000.

We applied RECLEVLEL_NR = 70,000 in our QA environment and performed regression testing to identify any 'concurrency lock' issues during the load or BADI process.

We found one specific case where the DM package '/CPMB/LOAD_INFOPROV_UI' failed with the error: 'Error obtaining concurrency lock (foreign_lock)'.

Please refer the attachment contains the steps to reproduce the issue in QDP system

Thank you

Regards

Samy

entry.title: Re: Advanced Event Mesh - Partitioned Queues : One Queue for All
entry.content:
Thanks for the reply Baris.

So, we want the messages to follow order FIFO. Our Publishing system is sending Notifications that needs to go to target. These notifications belonging to one work order should follow the order. Example: Notification ‘in progress’ for Work Order ‘123’ is sent before the notification ‘ Complete’ by the Sender (Pub) System. If for some reason the notification ‘in progress’ fails, then that should block all the messages of that work order. We don’t want to send ‘complete’ before ‘in progress’.

we can create an exclusive queue for this to maintain the order, but in case of failure all the work order messages will be blocked. In above case message of Order 123 should be blocked but other orders can still go to the target.

we need order with in one work order and I call that as one group. I am unable to find anything on Solace to address this and also I am looking for a solution with minimum custom development.

Thanks again for replying to my comment.

-Anuj
